lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen to a story and identify key characters and body parts mentioned.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Before story, say: “Listen for mouth, neck, legs.” As they hear them, students touch or circle the body part in the SB.
stretchStrategies: ❝Add-a-Line❞ – After reading and acting the story, challenge students to extend it by suggesting one more sentence each using a familiar body part. They can act out the new part too.
e.g., “Then the cat jumped up!” → “He’s got strong legs!”

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can read the story aloud, act it out, and answer questions using the target language.
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Read story aloud. Assign roles and repeat key lines chorally. Students act out while saying their lines.
stretchStrategies: ❝Add-a-Line❞ – After reading and acting the story, challenge students to extend it by suggesting one more sentence each using a familiar body part. They can act out the new part too.
e.g., “Then the cat jumped up!” → “He’s got strong legs!”

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can create a simple, imaginative ending to the story by drawing or acting it out.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Creativity) Show last story picture. Ask: “What could happen next?” Students act, draw, or describe a creative ending.

items: Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]
